questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions.

a. Why can humans neither change the sun's radiation nor the earth's orbit around the sun?

b. Describe how human beings are responsible for the increase in the greenhouse gases.

c. What do you think the main cause of the increase in carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere is?

d. Why enormous areas of forests are destroyed by the people every year? Describe in brief.

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) Humans can neither change the sun's radiation nor the earth's orbit around the sun, because these things are beyond their control.

(b) Human beings do some unwise activities like burning too much fossil fuels, setting up more factories, cutting down trees indiscriminately, etc. that result in the increase of greenhouse gases. Thus, they are responsible for the increase in the greenhouse gases.

(c) I think the main cause of the increase in carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels. With the increase of industrial activities, the combustion of coal has increased. Besides coal, mineral oil and natural gas are also burned for various purposes. Thus, every time a fossil raw material is burned, it releases carbon dioxide into the air.

(d) Enormous areas of forests are destroyed by the people every year to obtain wood and to clear regions for mining and to create pasture.

questions.uddipok:
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions:
SAARC is a regional organization for mutual cooperation, friendship and development. The full form of SAARC is "South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation". At the initial stage, there were only seven developing nations to form the organization. Later, Afghanistan was included as one of its member countries. SAARC started its journey through holding its first conference in Dhaka on 8 December 1985. At present, the member countries of this organization are Bangladesh, Bhutan, Maldives, Nepal, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan. The secretariat of this organization is situated in the capital of Nepal. Its head is called the Secretary General. There is a deep relationship between Bangladesh and SAARC. It was Bangladesh that took the first initiative to form SAARC. As the initiator of SAARC, Bangladesh has been playing a significant and strong role in its different activities. As one of the member countries, it has also been making every effort to expand the trade between the member countries and to solve the regional conflicts and existing crisis between the neighbouring countries.

Write a summary of the above passage in your own words.

sub_questions.explanation: SAARC (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation) is a regional organization for mutual cooperation, friendship and development. It began its journey in Dhaka on December 8, 1985. The member countries are Bangladesh, Bhutan, Maldives, Nepal, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan. Though Bangladesh is the initiator of this organization, its secretariat is in the capital of Nepal and its head is called Secretary General. Bangladesh maintains a deep relationship with SAARC and plays a significant role in the functioning of its various activities. Bangladesh is trying to expand trade and commerce among the member countries and solve different conflicts between the neighbouring countries.

(a) But his heart was not in medicine and he felt that he was born to be a poet.

sub_questions.explanation:
d + h + e + g + a + c + f + b d+h+e+g+a+c+f+b d + h + e + g + a + c + f + b
John Keats was born on October 31, 1795. He was the eldest son of his parents. He lost his father in 1804 and his mother in 1810. In 1811, Keats became an apprentice to a surgeon at Edmonton. But his heart was not in medicine and he felt that he was born to be a poet. Finally; he abandoned surgery for literature. His finest poems like 'Ode To a Nightingale', 'Ode On a 'Grecian Urn' etc were published in 1820. This great poet met a premature death on February 23, 1821.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions to write a paragraph on "A Tea Stall". You should write it in about 150 words.
(a) What is a tea stall?
(b) What kind of foods and drinks are sold in a tea stall?
(c) Where is it located?
(d) When do people come to take tea here?
(e) Why is it called a "Mini Sangsad"?

sub_questions.explanation:
A Tea Stall
A tea stall is a road side shop for people who go there to have tea as well as other snacks. A tea stall is very common both in towns and villages in our country. It usually sits at a crowded place. It is found in a market place, a square, a bus stand, a railway station and near schools and colleges. In a tea stall, usually, tea is served to the customers in exchange of money. But biscuits, bananas, cigarettes, betel leaves, some other snacks are also sold there. Though some tea stalls are well-furnished, most of them are poorly furnished. It is usually decorated with chairs, tables and benches. People go to a tea stall usually to take a cup of tea to remove their tiredness. A tea stall is kept open from early morning till late night. In a tea stall there are 'generally two people to manage and run it. One is a grown up man who prepares tea and takes bill from the customers, and the other is a young boy who serves tea, biscuits, etc. to the customers. Sometimes, people come to a tea stall in a group and raise a storm over the cup. They discuss about politics, daily affairs, various problems and what not. That is why, it is sometimes called a 'mini sangsad'. After all, it can be said that a tea stall is a useful place for many people.

questions.uddipok:
Read the beginning of a story. Add at least ten new sentences to complete the story. Give a suitable title to it.
Lina is a student of class ten. One day in the afternoon she was gossiping with her friend beside a pond near her house. While gossiping she noticed two small boys quarrelling over a trifling matter. She did not take it seriously thinking that their quarrel would come to an end soon. But ……..

sub_questions.explanation:
Lina's Ready Wit
Lina is a student of class ten. One day, in the afternoon she was gossiping with her friend beside a pond near her house. While gossiping she noticed two small boys quarrelling over a trifling matter. She did not take it seriously thinking that their quarrel would come to an end soon. But it turned out to be a serious one. At one point of time, one of the boys picked up a big stone to throw it to the other whereas the other boy started to throw pebbles at him one after another. Being hit by the pebbles, the boy with a heavy stone in his hand, became imbalanced and fell in the pond. In the water, he became so scared that he couldn't swim and started to drown. In the meantime, the other boy, being panicked, fled away. Lina and her friend saw the boy drowning and rushed to the spot. They cried for help but nobody was around. All of a sudden, Lina saw a fishing net nearby. She took the net and hurled it to the boy. When the boy got hold of the net, Lina and her friend pulled it with all their might and brought the drowning boy to the land. Meanwhile, some villagers gathered at the spot and took the boy to the hospital. The people then praised Lina for her ready wit and thus, she became a star of her village.

questions.uddipok: The pie chart below shows the interest of the students of a secondary school in different subjects. Describe the chart in about 150 words. You should highlight and summarize the information given in the chart.

sub_questions.explanation:
The pie chart shows the subject preferences of students in a secondary school. It highlights their interest in four key subjects: Mathematics, Science, Bangla, and English. According to the chart, Mathematics is the most preferred subject, with 35% of the students showing interest in it. This is followed by Science, which attracts 25% of the students. Bangla is also popular, drawing the attention of 23% of the students. English, however, is the least chosen subject, with only 17% showing interest in it.
From the data, it is clear that students tend to favor subjects related to logic and reasoning, such as Mathematics and Science, over languages. This could be due to the growing importance of science and technology in modern education and career paths. Nonetheless, the significant interest in Bangla reflects a continued appreciation for the mother tongue. Overall, the chart shows a balanced but slightly science-leaning academic interest among students.

questions.uddipok:
Suppose, you are Robin/Rubina. Your younger brother, Rana does not take physical exercise at all.
Now, write an e-mail telling him the importance of taking physical exercise.

sub_questions.explanation:
To : rana15@gmail.com
Subject : Informing the importance of physical exercise

Dear Rana,
I received your letter yesterday. It is praiseworthy that you're going well with your study. At the same time, I want to give you an advice to take physical exercise regularly. You know that "A sound mind remains in a sound body." So, to keep your body fit, you should take physical exercise daily. You are already suffering from leg pain. Still you are not taking any sort of physical exercise. If you avoid doing exercise on a regular basis, your body will get rusty. You will feel uneasy all the times. Without soundness in your body, you will be inattentive to your study. But you should become careful of the rules of exercise. Otherwise, it may hamper your health. You must have a proper guideline for this. I think, you will inform me your details soon.
How're our parents? Convey my best wishes to Tuhin and Shaon. No more today.

Your elder sister,
Rubina

questions.uddipok:
Suppose, you are Rohan/Raiyana reading in class ten. You along with your classmates want to make a garden in front of your school. So, you need to talk to the headmaster.
Now, write a dialogue between you and the headmaster about making a garden.

sub_questions.explanation:
Raiana : May I come in, sir?
Headmaster : Yes, please come in. Tell me, what can I do for you?
Raiana :  Sir, we would like to make a small garden in front of our school. There is a piece of land in front of our campus where the local cowboys graze their cattle. We want to use the land for making a small garden.
Headmaster : Well, that's a good idea. Who is going to execute the plan?
Raiana : We, the students of class ten, would execute the plan. Our honourable class teacher, Mrs Morshed gave her consent to coordinate the project.
Headmaster : Great! But you know, a garden needs to be taken care of. Are you ready to take the trouble? Besides, you cannot hamper your studies.
Raiana : Yes, sir. We have it in our mind. We'll take care of the garden properly. Again, when we become busy with studies, the students of class nine will take part in gardening. We will do it by turns.
Headmaster : I like your plan. Ok, I give you the permission. But you've to write an application to me for that.
Raiana : Sure, sir. We'll submit an application, tomorrow.
Headmaster : May Allah bless you.
Raiana : Thanks you, sir.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
a) Why is 21 February a memorable day in our national history?
b) Who is responsible to raise a storm of protest and how? Describe.
c) How did the Pakistani government try to prevent the protest?
d) What did the students of Dhaka University do against the declaration of outlạiving all sorts of public meetings and rallies?
e) How is Language Movement related to Independence Movement of Bángladesh?

sub_questions.explanation:
a. February 21 is a memorable day in our national history because on this day in 1952, the heroic son's of Bengal laid down their lives to establish Bangla as a state language of the undivided Pakistan. On this day, we pay tribute to the language martyrs because of their sacrifice for the rightful place of mother tongue.
b. The then Governor General of Pakistan, Mohammad Ali Zinnah, is responsible to raise a storm of protest. In a public meeting in Dhaka, he declared Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan, which disregarded the language rights of the Bangalee. Therefore, a mass protest started across the country.
c. The Pakistani government banned all sorts of public meetings and gatherings to stop the protest that began following Mohammad Ali Jinnah's declaration of Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan and continued non-stop.
d. Against the declaration of outlawing all sorts of public meeting and rallies, the students of Dhaka University brought out a peaceful protest procession on 21 February, defying the law.
e. The Language Movement of 1952 kindled the sparks of independence movement in East Pakistan by making the Bangalees aware of their rights. Thus, the Language Movement is related to the independence movement of Bangladesh.
